title: Shy heathwren
text:
The shy heathwren ("Hylacola cauta") is a species of small <a href="bird">bird</a> in the family <a href="Acanthizidae">Acanthizidae</a>, <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> to <a href="Australia">Australia</a>. They inhabit mostly <a href="Mallee%20%28habit%29">mallee</a> woodland that has relatively dense shrub and <a href="Heath%20%28habitat%29">heath</a> understorey. Shy heathwrens feed mostly on ground dwelling insects, and rarely on seeds. Their ground level nests are dome-shaped and usually concealed within grass <a href="Bunch%20grass">tussocks</a> or shrubs. Within the nest they typically lay 2–3 freckled and pinkish eggs.
The birds are cock-tailed with a chestnut rump that darkens towards the tip. Their feathers are white with brown streaking underneath and greyish-brown on the back and crown. They have a white eyebrow, tail tip and patch on the <a href="flight%20feather">flight feather</a>s, and a black <a href="Beak">bill</a>. Their eyes are brown to yellowish-brown and legs are slate-brown. Females have slightly duller colouring, and immature birds are duller again with some of these being fawn-coloured underneath. They have a total length when adults of .
They are uncommon residents across a wide part of southern Australia. Ranging from near <a href="West%20Wyalong%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">West Wyalong</a> in <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a> to the <a href="Murchison%20River%20%28Western%20Australia%29">Murchison River</a> in <a href="Western%20Australia">Western Australia</a>. In New South Wales, they are found in two isolated populations: one between <a href="Leeton%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Leeton</a>, Willandra, <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a>, <a href="Nymagee%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Nymagee</a> and West Wyalong; and the other from <a href="Balranald%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Balranald</a> to <a href="Trentham%20Cliffs%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Trentham Cliffs</a>. Within the state they are seen as a <a href="threatened">threatened</a> and <a href="vulnerable%20species">vulnerable</a>, largely due to human-wrought <a href="Habitat%20destruction">habitat loss</a>, and <a href="predation">predation</a> by foxes and cats.
Their <a href="Alpha%20taxonomy">taxonomic</a> name was formerly "Calamanthus cautus"—classing them as fieldwrens—until they were renamed in 2008. The generic name "Hylacola" derives from the Greek "hylē" 'woodland' and the Latin "-cola" 'dweller'. The specific epithet derives from the Latin "cautus" 'shy, wary'. Common names for the species include shy hylacola and mallee heathwren. Four subspecies have been recognised: the nominate subspecies "Hylacola cauta cauta" in South Australia and Victoria; "H. c. macrorhynchus" in New South Wales; "H. c. halmaturina" on <a href="Kangaroo%20Island">Kangaroo Island</a>; and "H. c. whitlocki" in Western Australia. 
References.
